Extract Hex Codes from Insper Color Palettes

Source: R/palette-utils.R
get_palette_colors.Rd

Extract hex color codes from Insper palettes for use in custom plots. This function provides direct access to palette colors, similar to RColorBrewer::brewer.pal().

Usage

get_palette_colors(palette, n = NULL, reverse = FALSE)

Arguments

palette

Character string indicating palette name. Use list_palettes to see available palettes. Common palettes include "main", "reds", "oranges", "teals", "grays", "red_teal", "bright", "contrast", "categorical".

n

Number of colors to return. If NULL (default), returns all colors in the palette. If n exceeds the palette size, colors will be recycled with a warning.

reverse

Logical. If TRUE, reverses the order of colors. Default is FALSE.

Value

Character vector of hex color codes.

Details

This function extracts colors from Insper palettes in discrete mode, meaning it returns the actual palette colors (possibly recycled) rather than interpolating new colors. For continuous color interpolation in ggplot2, use scale_color_insper_c or scale_fill_insper_c.

To explore available palettes visually, use show_insper_palette. To list all available palettes with metadata, use list_palettes.

See also

get_insper_colors for individual colors, list_palettes to see all palettes, show_insper_palette to visualize palettes, scale_color_insper_d for ggplot2 discrete scales

Other colors: get_insper_colors(), insper_pal(), list_palettes(), show_insper_colors(), show_insper_palette()

Examples

# Get 5 colors from the reds sequential palette
get_palette_colors("reds", n = 5)
#> [1] "#FEE5E7" "#FCA5A8" "#E4002B" "#A50020" "#6B0015"

# Get all colors from the main palette
get_palette_colors("main")
#> [1] "#E4002B" "#F15A22" "#FAA61A" "#009491" "#3CBFAE" "#414042"

# Get colors in reverse order
get_palette_colors("teals", n = 3, reverse = TRUE)
#> [1] "#006763" "#009491" "#27A5A2"

# Use in base R plots
colors <- get_palette_colors("bright", n = 3)
barplot(1:3, col = colors)


# Use in ggplot2 manual scales
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_manual(values = get_palette_colors("main", n = 3))
